Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Bridging Cognitive Science and Sensor Technology: Non-intrusive and Multi-modality Sensing in Human-Machine Interactions

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objectives of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) award are an integrated research and education plan focused on investigation of a non-intrusive biosensing paradigm and multi-modality cognitive inference approach for human-machine systems. The transformative nature of the paradigm under investigation is to build miniature sensing elements on machine surfaces, so that human physiological signals can be acquired non-intrusively in real-time through natural contacts during human-machine interactions. The new inference approach is inspired by human biological learning behaviors and aims to infer human cognitive states based upon individualized and multi-modality cues, including physiological signals, along with integration of various cue-state relation mechanisms. Two test-beds in transportation and medicine will be established to validate the theoretical work.

This project will transfer research outcomes into education curricula for a wide variety of trainees, including graduate, undergraduate, and K-12 students. Minorities and underrepresented groups will be recruited into this interdisciplinary field. This program will engage and train the general public through close interactions with government agencies, industries, and international collaborators. It is anticipated that the program will produce groundbreaking results in applying sensor technology to human cognitive system modeling, and have huge impacts on public safety and human health worldwide.

ProgramReference.Text: SENSORS AND SENSOR SYSTEMS FOR CIS

POR.DRECONTENT:
During this award period, accomplishments were made through a variety of sensing projects, through three specific aims. First, a non-intrusive natural-contact sensing paradigm was developed. A nano-scale bio-sensor (nano-skin) for measuring human temperature has been designed. A second aim of “individualized multi-modality cognitive state inference” focused on implementation of an eye tracker and a glove embedded with sensors to replace the traditional keyboard-mouse interface. In addition to the initial design, two additional cycles of updating and testing took place. This new interface was tested on patients with arthritis for the purpose of at home, tele-rehabilitation. Feedback from user experience through use of the System Usability Scale was gathered to provide updates to the glove and eye tracker interface. An additional novel interface scheme for cursor control using EEG signals and advanced neural networks methods has been accomplished. For the third aim “test-beds and verification”, an integrated networked multi-driving simulator platform has been built in the PI’s lab, which provides a safe and effective lab environment for interactive driving behavior studies. With the help of this multi-driving simulator platform, the PI’s lab has and will continue to help identify the genesis and features of car accidents.

 

Training and professional development were carried out during the course of this award. Dozens of graduate students were involved in this research. Some of them took part in collaborative activities with high school students, mentoring K-12 students… with Middle School on broader science awareness. Undergraduate students from the Industrial Engineering Capstone groups were educated in experimental design and testing. Under the guidance of our lab, the groups designed and ran tests to monitor physiological signals of subjects during virtual driving simulation and designed and ran tests to monitor stress levels of subjects who were tasked with piloting a quad copter across an obstacle course on university campus. Two courses were also taught at Northeastern University both in campus and on line. Biosensor and Human Behavior Measurement is a graduate/undergraduate level course that introduces students to the idea of biosensors, and shows how a variety of devices can be used to measure a wide range of aspects. Human Factors Engineering is a graduate course where students learn to properly consider human factors to identify design constraints, and are taught the tools needed to implement feasible solutions.

 This research has crucial impacts on the development of the principal discipline. For cognitive science, we propose to integrate different inference algorithms together which could be an effective means to deal with this difficulty. A computational-intelligence based inference method was created which mimics the decision making process in human society.  For sensor technology, a novel sensor design paradigm 'natural contact' has been made. Development of thin film sensors to make measurements through natural contact will provide future cognitive inference studies with the ability to collect physiological signals non-intrusively. This research also impacts other disciplines. The developed thin film heart rate sensor on clothing or on a potential natural contact surface can provide frequent, unprompted measurements for at-home, tele-health monitoring applications for a more realistic, real-time measurement of patient and athlete heart rates.
